title: 'You are welcome here' - Newcastle's message to immigrants, refugees and asylum seekers
text:
'You are welcome here' - Newcastle's message to immigrants, refugees and asylum seekers 11:30, 8 Jul 2016 Since the Brexit vote, a spike in racist hate crimes has been reported across the country - but Newcastle has opened its arms to foreign nationals Shares Get daily news by email L-R Tony Pierre, Cllr Mick Bowman, Anisha Malik, Shumel Raham and Cllr Dipu Ahad 
Asylum seekers, refugees and immigrants have been told they are welcome in Newcastle following a worrying spike in race hate crimes across the country. 
Newcastle City Council agreed to “convene a gathering of organisations and individuals of goodwill” to publicly endorse those currently calling the city home. 
The council also condemned the “anti-immigration narrative” which has come to the fore during the EU referendum debate. 
Liberal Democrat councillor David Faulkner said that those against multiculturalism had been emboldened by the Brexit vote. Cllr David Faulkner 'EDL not welcome here' Northumbria's police commissioner condemns hate crime 
He said: “Brexit has helped in the minds of people inimical to the cause of diversity and tolerance, it has helped normalise the views of those who do not agree with multiculturalism.” 
Coun Faulkner’s motion to full council, which was agreed, stated: “Council deplores the hostile and misleading anti-immigration narrative that the Leave side of the EU referendum campaign propagated and the way in which it has poisoned political discourse. 
“Council believes that the damage to community relations will be lasting and the encouragement to the far right a serious concern. 
“Newcastle is both a City of Sanctuary which welcomes asylum-seekers and refugees, and is a city in need of the skills that migrant labour bring.” 
Nine racist crimes were recorded by Northumbria Police in the days that followed the Brexit vote. Sean Gallup/Getty Images A Muslim family attends a street fest in immigrant-heavy Neukoelln district to celebrate the end of the Muslim month of Ramadan on July 5, 2016 in Berlin, Germany 
Reports of incidents of racism, believed to be fuelled by the result of the EU referendum, have been made across the country, and highlighted on social media. 
London Labour MP David Lammy said he has been subjected to a “barrage” of racist and threatening messages since the vote. 
He said: “I will continue to stand up for my constituents and what I believe in. 
“I was born here and I am very proud to be British, but the outpouring of hatred, xenophobia and racism unleashed in the wake of the EU referendum is not the Britain that I know.” 
Suspected racist graffiti was found on the front entrance of the Polish Social and Cultural Association (POSK) in Hammersmith, west London. 
And Cambridgeshire Police are investigating reports of racist laminated cards saying “Leave the EU/No more Polish vermin” being distributed in Huntingdon only hours after the leave result was announced. 
On Sunday, more than two million EU citizens living in Britain were left in fear that they may be deported after the Government refused to promise they can stay after Brexit. 
Home Secretary Theresa May, who is running for Prime Minister, stands accused of turning people into “bargaining chips” after holding back from giving a full-fledged guarantee. 
MPs claim the “deeply offensive” move has left children “in tears” and is “undermining the right to family life”. More on the EU Referendum
